case_title: PAHULAL VED PRAKASH vs COMMISSIONER OF INCOME TAX
reference_no_or_id: Income Tax Reference Application Nos. 32 and 34 of 1990
case_number: Income Tax Reference Application Nos. 32 and 34 of 1990
complaint_summary: The assessee, a partnership firm, was accused of concealing income and furnishing inaccurate particulars during the assessment year 1975-76.
investigation_summary: A search was conducted at the firm's premises, leading to the seizure of account books. Additional income of Rs.1,90,000 was disclosed under Section 273-A of the Income-tax Act, and reassessment proceedings revealed discrepancies such as bogus purchases, unexplained cash credits, and suppressed sales.
judgment_summary: The court rejected the applications filed by both the assessee and the Revenue. It upheld the penalty of Rs.1,06,417 imposed under Section 271(1)(c) of the Income-tax Act, concluding that the assessee knowingly understated its income and furnished inaccurate particulars.
punishment: Penalty of Rs.1,06,417 imposed under Section 271(1)(c) of the Income-tax Act.
legal_arguments: The assessee argued that the penalty orders were illegal and not according to law.
The Revenue contended that the penalty should be recomputed after final determination of income.
citations: Karnani Properties Ltd. v. C.I.T. [(1971) 82 I T R 547]
Hukumchand Mills Ltd. v. C.I.T. (1967) 63 I T R 232 (SC)
key_issues: Whether the penalty order was justified under Section 271(1)(c).
Whether the Tribunal was correct in directing penalty recomputation.
Whether the penalty order was liable to be quashed due to the penalty imposed being below the minimum limit.

issues_raised.question: Whether the Tribunal was justified in not cancelling the penalty order under section 271(1)(c) of the Income-tax Act, 1961?
Whether the penalty order was liable to be quashed due to the penalty imposed being below the minimum limit?

Whether the Tribunal was correct in law in directing that the penalty under section 271(1)(c) will be recomputed after final determination of income but not exceed the quantum of penalty presently under appeal?

tribunal_observations: Partners were aware of the concealed income.
Accountant acted with the consent and knowledge of partners.
No evidence of defalcation by the accountant.
key_findings.legal_conclusion: Concealment within the meaning of section 271(1)(c) established.

legal_terms.mens rea: The intention or knowledge of wrongdoing.

words_and_phrases.concealment: The act of hiding or not disclosing income.
words_and_phrases.under-totalling: Incorrectly summing up figures to reduce taxable income.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around penalty proceedings under Section 271(1)(c) of the Income-tax Act, 1961, for concealment of income and furnishing inaccurate particulars. The court upheld the penalty of Rs.1,06,417 imposed, rejecting the applications from both the assessee and the Revenue.
